general: Ofloxacin, FDA approved in 1990, is a fluoroquinolone with broad activity against respiratory and enteric pathogens.
Ofloxacin is a racemic mixture of R-ofloxacin and L-ofloxacin (levofloxacin).
For most clinical indications, levofloxacin is used rather than ofloxacin.
CDC no longer recommends fluoroquinolones (including ofloxacin) for gonococcal infections due to high levels of resistance (MMWR 2007;56:332).
See Fluoroquinolones, Overview for additional class-wide information.

adult_dose.dairy: Avoid dairy products ±2 hours of oral administration.
adult_dose.metal_cations: Concomitant metal cations: see Major Drug Interactions below.

renal_adjustment.crcl_or_egfr: CrCl >50: No dosage adjustment. CrCl 10-50: 200-400 mg q24h. CrCl <10: 200 mg q24h
renal_adjustment.hemodialysis: 200 mg q24h (give dialysis day dose AD)

adverse_effects: Detailed discussion of adverse effects: see Fluoroquinolones, Overview.

pregnancy_risk.fda_risk_category: Avoid in pregnancy due to possible renal, cardiac, and CNS toxicity in the fetus. Consider use if no alternatives exist, and if benefit outweighs risk.
pregnancy_risk.lactation: Avoid breastfeeding for 4-6 hrs after a dose, monitor infant for GI toxicity
pregnancy_risk.footnote: Capital letter = Old FDA risk category; Text = New FDA risk category

pharmacology.preparations: Tab (200, 300, 400 mg), 0.3% oph soln, 0.3% otic soln
